Project Number: 42436 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Republic of Palau: Implementing a Medium-Term 
Budget Framework 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

The currency of Palau is the United States dollar.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Palau's physical, geographical, and economic characteristics underscore the country's 
fragility. It has a small population and is vulnerable to external economic shocks, and climate 
change is affecting the stability of its formal and subsistence economies. Its dependency on aid 
for the delivery of core government functions exacerbates its vulnerability, particularly in the 
uncertain environment of the financial support of the Compact of Free Association1 and the 
global economic crisis. The emerging tourism sector is a driver of economic development. 
Palauans  are  committed  to  long-term  development  and  work  collaboratively  to  identify 
development priorities. 
 
2.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  partnership  strategy  (CPS)  for  Palau 
(2009–2013) focuses on three areas: (i) improving public sector effectiveness; (ii) facilitating 
private  sector  development,  including  through  the  provision  of  basic  infrastructure;  and 
(iii) managing the threat of climate change by improving environmental resilience.2 Included with 
improving public sector effectiveness is the implementation of a medium-term budget framework. 
The  CPS  directly  supports  implementation  of  Palau's  medium-term  development  strategy 
(MTDS) (2009–2014) including Palau's medium-term fiscal strategy (MTFS) in alignment with 
the objectives of the Paris Declaration on Aid Effectiveness.3 The MTDS sets Palau's overall 
development  objectives,  provides  a  forward  action  plan  for  all  line  ministries,  aligns  with 
Strategy 2020,4 and builds upon Working in Fragile Environments: A Midterm Review of the 
Pacific Strategy 2005–2009.5 
 
3.  The  proposed  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)—Implementing  a 
Medium-Term Budget Framework—is designed to strengthen the budget framework in Palau. 
This will help the Government achieve its MTFS by providing information to enable it to (i) use 
scarce fiscal resources in an efficient manner; and (ii) move toward greater self-reliance with 
respect  to  financing  government  expenditure.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. The TA is part of a longer-term program of support for Palau. Under previous TA,6 
ADB provided support to develop Palau's MTDS and MTFS. This TA is the next step in that 
process—building on the MTDS and MTFS, and making those strategies operational through 
the budgeting process. In addition, the Palau CPS includes this TA within a broader framework 
of capacity development support. 
 
4.  In conceptualizing the assistance, consultations were conducted during preparation of 
the CPS.7 Particular consultations on the TA concept paper were conducted from 13 to 15 May 
2009  and  on  24  July  2009.8 The  major  agreements  with  the  Government  on  the  impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference are reflected in this TA paper.

II.  ISSUES 
5.  Palau’s fiscal position is unsustainable due to limited domestic revenues and a large 
government wage bill. From FY1995 to FY 2006, domestic revenue covered an average of just 
40% of total expenditure. Grants, concessional loans, and drawdowns from the Compact of 
Free Association Trust Fund covered the rest. The public services wages and salaries bill has 
been the fastest-growing component of current expenditure, rising from a share of 40.6% in 
FY1995  to  50.5%  in  FY2006.  In  addition,  while  the  design  of  budget  and  performance 
management systems is broadly sound, implementation of these systems is weak. The Ministry 
of Finance has limited capacity to analyze and refine budget submissions to fit with its fiscal 
constraints and align with development objectives. 
 
6.  Recognizing  these  issues,  in  May  2008  the  Pacific  Financial  Technical  Assistance 
Centre (PFTAC), at the request of ADB and the Palau Government, carried out a scoping study 
to  look  at  options  for  developing  a  medium-term  budget.9 The  study  found  that  while  the 
principle of medium-term budgeting is well recognized in the Palau Budget Reform Act, 2001, 
systems and capacity are needed to ensure that fiscal forecasts are developed on a medium-
term basis. 
 
7.  A medium-term budget is one part of a financial management framework, which includes 
an MTFS and a medium-term expenditure framework. An MTFS provides a top–down statement 
of fiscal policy objectives and sector strategies;10 a medium-term budget framework sets out 
projections of spending by individual agencies and allocates resources in line with strategic 
priorities  over  the  medium  term;  and  a  medium-term  expenditure  framework  extends  the 
analysis with more detailed costing within sectors and with performance measures. 
 
8.  The PFTAC scoping study set out a timetable for implementing a medium-term budget in 
Palau over two budget cycles. Key recommendations include (i) preparing and enhancing fiscal 
and  macroeconomic  frameworks  and  forecasts;  (ii)  improving  revenue  projection  capacity; 
(iii) enhancing the capacity to prepare and analyze budget submissions; and (iv) introducing a 
cash management and internal audit process. 
 
9.  Fiscal and Macroeconomic Frameworks and Forecasts. Palau's MTFS focuses on 
the country becoming more self-reliant with respect to financing government expenditure. The 
key actions are to (i) undertake comprehensive, effective, and fair tax reform; (ii) significantly 
reduce current government expenditure; and (iii) improve government efficiency (footnote 10).  
The  current  fiscal  strategy  includes  only  broad  financial  estimates,  which  do  not  guide 
implementation. The macroeconomic capacity of the Ministry of Finance also needs to be 
strengthened  and  projections  need  to  be  made  with  a  medium-term  perspective. 
Macroeconomic data need to be refined and systematized for use in the projections. 
 
10.  Revenue Projection. The process of projecting revenue needs to be strengthened, 
especially for the medium term. Currently, the generally conservative revenue estimates are 
based on trends. The revenue projection model, previously developed for the budgeting process, 
was not utilized for FY2010. It needs to be reviewed to ensure it remains relevant and is 
incorporated within existing processes.

11.  Budget  Submissions.  While  the  Ministry  of  Finance  provides  line  ministries  with 
instructions on procedures to be followed and the content of budget submissions, it does not 
provide detailed parameters, including economic parameters that can be effectively used in 
costing programs on a medium-term basis. In addition, line ministries' capacity to soundly cost 
existing and new policies needs to be strengthened. Performance reports of the line ministries, 
indicating performance against targets, need to be developed. In addition, Ministry of Finance 
capacity to critically analyze budget submissions from line ministries and to provide feedback on 
performance needs to be enhanced. 
 
12.  Cash Management and Internal Audit. The Government needs to set up a formal cash 
planning system (including investment planning and debt management) to enable it to allocate 
resources to line ministries in a more predictable manner and to allow better service delivery 
based on predictability of resources. Furthermore, no internal audit function is in place to guide 
and advise the Ministry of Finance and line ministries. As a preliminary step to dealing with the 
first of these concerns, PFTAC has developed a cash management manual for Palau and is in 
discussions with the Government to provide a training seminar on implementing the manual. 
The recently completed report, An Evaluation of Internal Audit in Pacific Countries: The Way 
Forward,11 includes Palau as one of the countries studied. ADB TA for Strengthening Public 
Financial Management in Pacific Developing Member Countries includes regional support for 
developing internal audit.12 
 
13.  The TA will work with the Ministry of Finance (including the Forecasting Committee 
made up of representatives from the Bureau of Budget and Planning, Bureau of Revenue, 
Customs and Tax, Bureau of National Treasury, and Statistics Department) and line ministries 
to provide support to develop and implement a medium-term budget framework. 
 
14.  Specifically,  the  TA  will  focus  on  three  areas:  (i)  strengthening  the  overall  budget 
framework  by  providing  support  to  improve  macroeconomic  data  and  revenue  forecasting; 
(ii) supporting line ministries to prepare budgets consistent with the framework by, for example, 
providing  assistance  with  costing  policies  over  the  medium  term  and  developing  key 
performance targets to monitor performance; and (iii) supporting the Ministry of Finance to 
analyze budget submissions and prepare a consolidated budget consistent with the framework 
and the MTFS. 
 
15.  TA implementation will consider the findings from the recently completed report into 
Pacific capacity development.13 While the Ministry of Finance in Palau is responsive to change 
and is starting from a reasonably high skill base, the ministry is small and the intended outputs 
will need to progress at an appropriate pace given its capacity. The study notes that TA 
effectiveness depends largely on human dynamics, which are shaped by the advisers' personal 
and professional qualities. The study notes that much also hinges on the extent to which the 
processes allow local partners to use their own capacity (existing or emergent) to find their own 
solutions to their particular challenges. Working within existing systems, which are broadly 
sound, will be important to TA success. In addition, the TA will recruit a national consultant 
during TA implementation to support the delivery of TA outputs.

16.  Furthermore,  ADB's  recently  completed  special  evaluation  study  provides 
recommendations that will be incorporated into TA implementation.14 The study identifies that 
line agencies require more sustained capacity development assistance than oversight agencies; 
accordingly, the TA will focus support on selected line ministries. Consistent with the study 
recommendations, an information program for awareness raising and understanding of the TA 
will be developed. The information program will consider mechanisms for enhancing community 
awareness (particularly business groups) and where possible integrating civil society and other 
stakeholder representatives in the process. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
17.  The impact of the TA will be a strengthened budget framework in Palau. The outcome of 
the TA is a medium-term budget framework that aligns with the MTDS. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
18.  The TA is intended to deliver the following outputs in the period from February 2010 to 
February 2013. 
 
19.  Fiscal Policy Framework Updated Annually. The TA will work with the Ministry of 
Finance to prepare a fiscal policy framework that is consistent with the MTFS. The framework 
will include medium-term financial estimates and be based on up-to-date macroeconomic data. 
The fiscal policy framework will be a rolling document that will be updated annually and used to 
guide preparation of the medium-term budget. 
 
20.  Revenue  Projection  Model  For  Producing  Medium-Term  Forecasts. The TA will 
work with the Ministry of Finance to (i) review the existing revenue projection model; and 
(ii) update the model based on this review and integrate it with the budget process. 
 
21.  Annual  Budgets  of  Selected  Line  Ministries  Consistent  with  the  Fiscal  Policy 
Framework. The TA will work with the Ministry of Health; Ministry of Education; and Ministry of 
Public Infrastructure, Industries and Commerce to (i) cost their programs on a medium-term 
basis based on the fiscal policy framework; and (ii) develop key performance targets to monitor 
the performance of the line ministries against the budget. 
 
22.  Consolidated Medium-Term Government Budget Consistent with the Fiscal Policy 
Framework and the MTFS. The TA will work with the Ministry of Finance to prepare a budget 
document that is consistent with the fiscal policy framework and the MTFS. As part of this 
process, the TA will support the ministry to critically analyze budget submissions from line 
ministries. 
 
23.  To contribute to the delivery and sustainability of these outputs, a half-day seminar will 
be held early during TA implementation for elected representatives on the TA approach and 
outputs. The seminar will also provide an overview of medium-term budgeting. Support to the 
Ministry of Finance and the selected line ministries will be primarily provided through mentoring 
and on-the-job training. One-day seminars will be held for the Ministry of Finance and selected 
line ministries to outline the fiscal policy framework once complete, and advise on the budget

C.  Cost and Financing 
24.  The TA is estimated to cost $560,000 equivalent. The Government has requested ADB 
financing of $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The Government will finance the balance of the cost, 
equivalent  to  $60,000,  through  provision  of  office  space,  communications  facilities  for 
consultants, and other in-kind contributions. Appendix 2 provides details of the cost estimates 
and  financing  plan.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  the  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook.16 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
25.  The Ministry of Finance (Bureau of Budget and Planning) will be the Executing Agency 
and Implementing Agency for the TA. The Ministry of Health; Ministry of Education; and Ministry 
of Public Infrastructure, Industries, and Commerce will be the selected line ministries to be 
supported under the TA. 
 
26.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months, starting in February 2010. The TA will 
finance up to 10 person-months of international consulting services and 22 person-months of 
national consulting services. The international consultants will comprise (i) a budget expert and 
team leader (international, 8 person-months, intermittent); and (ii) an economist (international, 2 
person-months, intermittent). The national consultant—a budget adviser—will be employed for 
the duration of the TA (22 person-months, intermittent). The expected completion date of the TA 
is June 2013. 
 
27.  ADB  will  engage  an  international  consulting  firm  using  the  quality-  and  cost-based 
selection  method  (80:20)  and  through  biodata  technical  proposals  in  accordance  with  the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3. The TA will not require any procurement. 
 
28.  Implementation of TA activities needs to be consistent with the system of Government in 
Palau (which is largely based on the United States system). Accordingly, experience in the 
northern  Pacific—and  an  understanding  of  financial  and  budget  processes  in  systems  of 
Government  that  follow  or  are  modeled  on  United  States  systems—are  considered  highly 
desirable criteria in consultant selection. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
29.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Republic of Palau for Implementing a Medium-Term Budget Framework, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The proposed work under this technical assistance (TA) will be implemented during 2010–
2013 to cover three full budget cycles (FY2011, FY2012, and FY2013). The first budget cycle will 
focus on enhancing the capacity of line ministries, the second will focus on enhancing capacity of 
the Ministry of Finance, and the third will focus on ensuring TA outputs are embedded into existing 
operations. 
 
2.  All  consultants  will  be  briefed  by  staff  from  the  Palau  Government  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) prior to commencing work. Consultants will be required to review all 
relevant literature prior to beginning work, including: (i) the Palau country partnership strategy;1  
(ii) Republic of Palau 2008: Achieving Sustainable Development;2 (iii) Medium-Term Development 
Strategy: Actions for Palau's Future and accompanying Explanatory Booklet;3 (iv) Assessment 
Mission to Introduce a Medium-Term Budget in Palau and Requisite Technical Assistance Needs;4 
(v)  Learning  from  Success;5 and  (vi)  ADB  Support  for  Public  Sector  Reforms  in  the  Pacific: 
Enhance Results through Ownership, Capacity, and Continuity.6 
 
A.  Budget Expert and Team Leader (international, 8 person-months, intermittent) 
3.  The budget expert and team leader will have extensive experience (more than 15 years) in 
a public finance role and be experienced in budget formulation, implementation, and monitoring. 
Experience gained from working in a ministry of finance (or equivalent) in a capacity development 
role is highly desirable. Experience in developing countries in the Pacific (particularly the northern 
Pacific) is highly desirable. An understanding of financial and budget processes in systems of 
government that follow or are modeled on United States systems is also highly desirable. 
 
4.  Working under the guidance of the Ministry of Finance, and working closely with Ministry of 
Finance staff, the budget expert will have overall responsibility for developing and implementing a 
medium-term budget framework. Integral to this role will be the provision of training, knowledge 
transfer, and mentoring. Specifically the budget expert will 
 
(i)  analyze current strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities for improvement in the 
current budget process; 
(ii)  prepare a fiscal policy framework that is consistent with the medium-term fiscal 
strategy and includes medium-term financial estimates; 
(iii)  review the existing revenue projection model and update the model based on this 
review and integrate the model with the budget process; 
(iv)  develop the existing Ministry of Finance budget preparation guidance materials to 
assist line ministries with budgeting over the medium term; 
(v)  prepare a budget assessment framework to enhance the capacity of the Ministry of 
Finance to analyze budget submissions;

5.  The budget expert will also undertake the role of team leader and in this role will 
 
(i)  ensure the expectations of the Government and ADB for the delivery of the TA are 
well understood and articulated to other team members; 
(ii)  coordinate the work and inputs of the consultancy team, and consult with relevant 
members of the Government; 
(iii)  act as the primary interface with the Government to ensure the appropriate and 
timely delivery of TA objectives; 
(iv)  provide leadership and guidance to the consultancy team, ensuring the quality and 
timeliness of all elements of the TA; 
(v)  ensure all consultant inputs are directed by a work plan; 
(vi)  establish  hand-over  milestones,  and  for  each  milestone  ensure  criteria  for 
demonstrated progress and commitment are established; 
(vii)  ensure the materials developed under the TA can be incorporated into existing 
processes to ensure sustainability; 
(viii)  liaise with PFTAC over the delivery of TA outputs; and 
(ix)  maintain close contact with the Government and the TA project officer. 
 
6.  PFTAC  will  act  in  an  advisory  and  review  capacity  as  the  TA  progresses,  including 
reviewing the work plans of the consultancy team and being involved in the review and delivery of 
seminar materials. PFTAC and ADB will undertake regular review missions to monitor progress 
against TA outputs. 
 
B.  Economist (international, 2 person-months, intermittent) 
7.  The economist will have extensive experience (more than 10 years) in preparing fiscal 
frameworks and undertaking macroeconomic analysis and modeling. Experience in developing 
countries in the Pacific (particularly the northern Pacific) is highly desirable. 
 
8.  Working under the guidance of the team leader, the economist will assist the team leader 
and the budget adviser with developing and implementing a medium-term budget framework. 
Working closely with the Ministry of Finance staff, the economist will

(i)  analyze strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities for improvement in the current 
approach  to  developing  the  fiscal  framework  and  underlying  macroeconomic 
analysis for budget preparation; 
(ii)  prepare a fiscal policy framework that is consistent with the medium-term fiscal

(iii)  review existing macroeconomic data used in projections and consider options for

(iv)  contribute to a draft report and final report. 
 
C.  Budget Adviser (national, 22 person-months, intermittent) 
9.  The budget adviser will have experience in a finance role. Experience in budget formulation, 
implementation, and monitoring is highly desirable. Experience gained from working in a ministry of 
finance (or equivalent) is highly desirable. 
 
10.  Working under the guidance of the team leader, the budget adviser will assist the team 
leader and the economist with developing and implementing a medium-term budget framework. 
The budget adviser will be required to work closely with the Ministry of Finance and line ministries 
to  enhance  the  budget  process.  The  budget  adviser  will  be  required  to  progress  the 
implementation of TA activities while the budget expert (team leader) is not in-country. 
 
11.  Specifically, the budget adviser will be required to support implementation of TA activities to 
be delivered by the budget expert (team leader): 
 
(i)  analyze current strengths, weaknesses, and opportunities for improvement in the 
current budget process; 
(ii)  prepare a fiscal policy framework that is consistent with the medium-term fiscal 
strategy and includes medium-term financial estimates; 
(iii)  review the existing revenue projection model, update the model based on the review, 
and integrate the model with the budget process; 
(iv)  develop the existing Ministry of Finance budget preparation guidance materials to 
assist line ministries with budgeting over the medium term; 
(v)  prepare a budget assessment framework to enhance the capacity of the Ministry of 
Finance to analyze budget submissions; 
(vi)  develop a small number of key performance measures for line ministries to monitor 
performance against targets; 
(vii)  prepare a consolidated medium-term government budget consistent with the fiscal 
policy framework and the medium-term fiscal strategy; 
(viii)  develop and implement, in conjunction with PFTAC, a half-day seminar for elected 
representatives on the TA approach and outputs, and an overview of medium-term 
budgeting; 
(ix)  develop  and  implement  three  1-day  seminars,  in  conjunction  with  PFTAC,  for 
selected line ministries to outline the fiscal policy framework and advise on the 
budget preparation process; 
(x)  ensure Palau's medium-term development strategies are factored into the budget 
process; 
(xi)  consider the options available to ensure all development assistance is incorporated 
into the budget process; and 
(xii)  prepare a draft report and a final report with input from the budget adviser and the 
economist.

12  Appendix 3 
 
12.  The  budget  adviser  will  develop  an  information  program  for  awareness-raising  and 
understanding  of  the  TA.  The  information  program  will  consider  mechanisms  for  enhancing 
community awareness (particularly business groups) and (if possible) integrating civil society and 
other  stakeholder  representatives  in  the  process.  The  budget  adviser  will  put  in  place  the 
arrangements for independent monitoring of the design and monitoring framework of the TA. 
 
13.  The budget adviser will also be required to provide ADB in-country support activities as 
directed by the Palau country specialist, Pacific Department (ADB).
